bestBHT.bht: Jesus questions whether it is proper to make men fast and mourn during a festival solemnity, indicating that as the bridegroom, it is not conceivable for his disciples to live an austere and mortified life while he is physically present with them.

Henry Alford: 34.] I have remarked on the striking contrast between make to fast and they shall (or, will) fast, on Matthew, ver. 15.
Marvin Vincent: Children of the bride - chamber. Better, as Rev., sons [νιους] . See on Mark 2:19.
Philip Schaff: Luke 5:34. Can ye make, etc. Luke brings out the reason why the objectors must fail to make the disciples fast.
Archibald T. Robertson: Can ye (μη δυνασθε). So Luke, adding
make , ποιησα, where Mark and Matthew have μη δυναντα. All three have μη and expect the answer no.
John Gill: Can ye make the children of the bride chamber fast, while the bridegroom is with them?" - Jesus questions the disciples of John and the Scribes and Pharisees about the possibility of fasting while the bridegroom is present.

signifying, that he was the bridegroom, and his disciples the children of the bride chamber" - This statement indicates that Jesus is the bridegroom, and his disciples are likened to the children of the bride chamber.

so it was not to be thought, that whilst Christ was corporeally present with his disciples, that they should be prevailed upon to live such an austere and mortified life" - The commentary expresses the thought that it is not conceivable for Jesus' disciples to live an austere and mortified life while Christ is physically present with them.
John Wesley: Can ye make — That is, is it proper to make men fast and mourn, during a festival solemnity?

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus questions the disciples of John and the Scribes and Pharisees about the possibility of fasting while the bridegroom is present, signifying that he is the bridegroom and his disciples are like the children of the bride chamber. The commentary explains that it is not conceivable for Jesus' disciples to live an austere and mortified life while Christ is physically present with them, suggesting that fasting and mourning should not be expected during a festival solemnity.

Jesus questions whether it is proper to make men fast and mourn during a festival solemnity, indicating that as the bridegroom, it is not conceivable for his disciples to live an austere and mortified life while he is physically present with them.

Jesus questions whether it is possible for the disciples of John and the Scribes and Pharisees to make the children of the bride chamber fast while the bridegroom is still with them. This indicates that he sees himself as the bridegroom and his disciples as the children of the bride chamber. It signifies that it is not conceivable for Jesus' disciples to live a rigorous and ascetic life while he is physically present with them. Therefore, it would not be appropriate to expect them to fast and mourn during a festive celebration.

Jesus questions whether it is possible for the disciples of John and the Scribes and Pharisees to make the children of the bride chamber fast while the bridegroom is still with them. This indicates that it is not conceivable for Jesus' disciples to live an austere and mortified life while Christ is physically present with them. Therefore, he questions the propriety of making men fast and mourn during a festival solemnity.

Jesus challenges the ability of John's disciples and the Scribes and Pharisees to make the children of the bride chamber fast while the bridegroom is still with them. This statement signifies that he sees himself as the bridegroom and his disciples as the children of the bride chamber. It suggests that it would not be appropriate to impose a strict and austere lifestyle on Jesus' disciples while he is physically present with them. Therefore, Jesus questions the suitability of fasting and mourning during a joyful celebration.
